section.title: Eclipse BPMN 2.0 Modeler
section.para: The Eclipse BPMN 2.0 Modeler allows you to specify business processes, choreographies, etc. using the BPMN 2.0 XML syntax (including BPMNDI for the graphical information). The editor itself is based on the Eclipse Graphiti framework and the Eclipse BPMN 2.0 EMF meta-model.
Features:

itemizedlist.listitem: It supports almost all BPMN 2.0 process constructs and attributes (including lanes and pools, annotations and all the BPMN2 node types).
Support for the few custom attributes that jBPM5 introduces.

Allows you to configure which elements and attributes you want use when modeling processes (so we can limit the constructs for example to the subset currently supported by jBPM5, which is a profile we will support by default, or even more if you like).

section.para: Many thanks go out to the people at Codehoop that did a great job in creating a first version of this editor.

section.para: You can use a simple wizard to create a new BPMN 2.0 process (under File -> New - Other ... select BPMN - BPMN2 Diagram).

section.title: Filtering elements and attributes
section.para: You can define which of the BPMN 2.0 elements and attributes you want to use when describing your BPMN 2.0 diagrams. Since the BPMN 2.0 specification is rather complex and includes a very large set of different node types and attributes for each of those nodes, you may not want to use all of these elements and attributes in your project. Elements and attributes can be enablement / disabled at the project level using the BPMN2 preferences category (right-click your project folder and select Properties ... which will open up a new dialog). The BPMN2 preferences contain an entry for all supported elements and attributes (per node type) and you can enable or disable each of those by (un)checking the box for each of those elements and attributes.

section.title: Adding custom task nodes
section.para: When creating and adding <task> or other <task> type nodes to a process, you might want to add input and output parameters to the node. Furthermore, you can configure jBPM to use custom WorkItemHandler implementations in conjunction with these nodes. These WorkItemHandler instances will then be used when your service node is reached.

The concept of customizing <task> and other <task>-type nodes and using custom WorkItemHandler implementations with these nodes is referred to as creating custom work items within jBPM. More information about this can be found in the chapter.

The following sections cover the following node types:
Task Service Task Send Task Receive Task Manual Task*

tip.para: A Manual Task should be used to represent a human activity that is not managed by the process engine or the human-task component. In this case, you would probably create a custom WorkItemHandler implementation that would interface with a technical component that the actor would use to indicate completion of the task.
However, if you were using a human task server, such as the jBPM human-task component, then you would use a User Task node instead.

section.title: Changing editor behavior
section.para: The "General settings" tab in the User Preferences lets you specify a "Target Runtime" which customizes the editor's behavior for a specific BPMN execution environment. Currently only jBPM5 and a generic runtime are defined for the editor, but others are in the works.
This preference page (shown below) also lets you configure default values for BPMN Diagram Interchange (or "DI") attributes.
